paragraphs.text: Habit reprogramming may be the answer, and a cure.

I’ve been reading Duhigg’s “The Power of Habit” after hearing him on a podcast. One of the fascinating things about habit research is that we overwrite old habits but they are still there. You can see the basics at http://charlesduhigg.com/how-habits-work/ where he describes…

paragraphs.text: I think that this depends on the genre you are reading. It’s clearly that novel and fiction will generate vivid pictures and great details, because writers are meant to make in that way. Instead, This is not valid for non fiction books, because you cannot image a habit or a mindset changing as easily as your novel characters. You could do surely, but would be a bit unnatural and less imaginative.

content.subtitle: This is not a metaphor. Take what follows literally.

paragraphs.name: f991
paragraphs.text: My Real Life Superpower

paragraphs.name: b333
paragraphs.text: This is not a metaphor. Take what follows literally.

virtuals.subtitle: This is not a metaphor. Take what follows literally.

paragraphs.name: 4eb7
paragraphs.text: Thanks for this article! You describe exactly what it was like for me to read fantasy and sci-fi when I was younger. My most vivid memories of books I’ve read are not words or sentences, they are scenes in 3D that move and have as much life as any 3D video-game.
“My Big ToE” book from Thomas Campbell.

paragraphs.name: 3cfd
paragraphs.text: I am downloading it as we speak. Looks interesting. Thanks!

ca686d5d9b.title: I am downloading it as we speak. Looks interesting. Thanks!

e94d80013c02.title: Also, if you want to learn more about this power, I highly recommend checking out “My Big ToE" book…

paragraphs.name: 22c1
paragraphs.text: SUPER. USEFUL. INFORMATION. Thank you, Andy! I have been on the wait list for months to check out “The Power of Habit” from my local library, but now I’m just going to go to Amazon and buy it. Thank you for this!

content.subtitle: Every time you ‘render’ a new piece of information,you contribute to your edification, like minuscule Legos creating a robust stronghold.

paragraphs.name: 5ef5
paragraphs.text: Working on 3-d visualization is like a muscle. You start small, colors, sound, humanoid shapes, emotions. Then you work your way up, textures, shade(in books you usually have omnipresent vision it is difficult to forget about the elephant in the scene after you read about it), heat, pain.

f65aae88988f.title: Working on 3-d visualization is like a muscle.

virtuals.subtitle: Every time you ‘render’ a new piece of information,you contribute to your edification, like minuscule Legos creating a robust stronghold.

paragraphs.name: 9dfd
paragraphs.text: Should someone call my name or tap me on the shoulder, I would immediately snap back to normal awareness and respond appropriately. So, if I was reading in the throes of some kind of kid self-hypnosis, it was a light trance that was easily broken — but it was also one that was easily reestablished. Once the distraction was dealt with, I could reliably, every time, return to my book and within a paragraph or two be right back in that state of total cinematic immersion.

paragraphs.name: d803
paragraphs.text: I want my superpower back! I’m setting a goal this year to research “reading and the brain,” and if possible, to regain the ability to experience fiction with full 3-D cinematic immersion. If I figure it out, I promise I’ll share the secret here on Medium. We can all be superheroes and traverse the stars together.

paragraphs.name: bdbe
paragraphs.text: OK, there’s a clue in that. While I haven’t experienced the full self-vanishing described here since my late teens, I do recognize different levels of ordinary immersion when reading, depending on the writer. I have developed a special affection for Alice Hoffman for exactly this reason. There is something about the way she writes that practically animates the reader’s brain for them. Her prose is written like poetry, and maybe that is a key. My favorite writer since I discovered him in the 5th grade is Ray Bradbury, I think for this very same reason. There’s more than just a good story being told. The language itself is like an incantation. If you know of more writers like that, let me know! Thanks A!

paragraphs.name: c152
paragraphs.text: That is so interesting, Lochlan. Maybe there is some real connection between the meanings we try to communicate to one another through fiction, and the meaning whispered to us by the unconscious mind in sleeping dreams. Connection as in via the same mechanism in consciousness. How much meaning, on how many levels, do our brains perceive all the time? And us mostly unaware of it? My sense from studying dreams/dream interpretation is that the “tantalising just beyond reach” feeling on waking means we really have perceived an important meaning, we just can’t quite remember it. Which means its in there, in our minds, effecting us even if we never grasp it consciously. What power gripping fiction can/must have on us, too. Deep stuff. I have to give this some real thought! Thanks, Lochlan!

paragraphs.name: 6aa1
paragraphs.text: This seems to have really jumped out as a theme in the responses to this essay, and it’s one I never seriously considered before posting it. I’m learning a lot from everyone sharing their experience. I’m starting to think that when the powers that be go on and on about the benefits of a college education, they need to list the hazards, too. This is a big one. “Learning how to learn” from written texts, and even learning how to academically appreciate literary writing, can steal our ability to enjoy reading, to read from a non-academic POV. That’s a mighty theft, there. My thought is that there has to be a way to do both. Academia presents it as an either/or, a trade one has to make in order to succeed in adult fields. I’m hoping that’s BS, an artifact of the way college is taught, not something inherent in our brains. Thanks, Pauls!
